news_summary: Today's environment news highlights progress in reducing the financial and ecological costs of retail returns, promoting sustainable practices at home, and advancing global accountability for climate action through potential reparations.
news_summary_fr: L'actualité environnementale d'aujourd'hui met en lumière les progrès réalisés en matière de réduction des coûts financiers et écologiques des retours de marchandises, de promotion des pratiques durables à domicile et de responsabilisation mondiale en matière d'action climatique par le biais de réparations potentielles.
news_summary_es: Las noticias medioambientales de hoy destacan los avances en la reducción de los costes financieros y ecológicos de las devoluciones al por menor, la promoción de prácticas sostenibles en el hogar y el fomento de la responsabilidad mundial por la acción climática a través de posibles reparaciones.

articles.title: Guest Idea: Avoiding the Financial and Environmental Impact of Retail Returns
articles.summary:
Over the last decade, retail returns have devolved from a straightforward, standard practice to a...
The post Guest Idea: Avoiding the Financial and Environmental Impact of Retail Returns appeared first on Earth911.
articles.content:
Over the last decade, retail returns have devolved from a straightforward, standard practice to a complex maze of fraud, logistics challenges, and wasted resources.

It all started with Amazon and the expectation of free returns, which the industry had to match to compete. Larger businesses that can afford to offer returns for free have really hurt smaller businesses that have to both reimburse the customer and eat the reverse logistics costs. According to Shopify, 68% of people search for brands that offer free returns. This expectation has also led to the next reason for increasing costs: overbuying.

With the rise of e-commerce, shopping from home has become a regular feature of daily life. According to Capital One shopping, 80.4% of Americans now shop online. They are buying clothes in multiple sizes in anticipation of returning the ones that don’t fit. Unfortunately, they also send back a variety of products that aren’t what they expected and that they would not have purchased if they had seen it first in a store. Not only are returns more expensive for retailers, but they have increased exponentially with the rise in e-commerce.

The Financial Cost of Retail Returns

The financial burden of returns is very high. Today, the average cost to a business to return an item is between $25 and $35. The reverse logistics cost involves not just the shipping label but also the handling, restocking, and reselling of goods. Not to mention, the item may be damaged, unsellable, or out-of-season, so it may take up valuable space on the shelves with nowhere to go.

There are a few industries that struggle the most with costly returns:

Big & Bulky: Returning large furniture is nearly impossible without being cost-prohibitive. Regulations in many states prohibit the resale of mattresses, and shipping them would incur very high costs.

Foreign Imports: Brands that import into the U.S. often have only a few warehouses, so each return must travel thousands of miles to replenish stock. Usually, the price of the item is less than the cost of returning it.

Underwear/Swimsuits: Items like these cannot be resold to others once opened, leaving the business with no way to recoup any return costs.

Due to the introduction of “Keep it Returns” by Amazon, fraud has been increasing. These programs are implemented when it’s less costly for the customer to keep the item and get reimbursed than to return it to the warehouse. As a result, millions of people are taking advantage of this policy and buying items they plan to return, only to be told to keep them. Astoundingly, 52% of consumers have participated in return fraud or abuse at least once in their lifetime, which just compounds the already high costs of returns.

The Environmental Impact of Retail Returns

The negative environmental impact of returns is astronomical. Unfortunately, 2.6 million tons of e-commerce returns end up in landfills, as it is cheaper to discard them than to process and resell them. In the U.S. alone in 2020, shipping returns from online orders generated 16 million metric tons of carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, equivalent to the emissions produced by powering 2 million homes for a year.

Retailers have to watch their bottom lines, but the amount of waste has gotten out of control. Consumers are also increasingly concerned about sustainability, which has led to the rise of transparency and eco-friendly business practices among brands like Patagonia, J.Crew, Room & Board, Lululemon, and countless others. While these efforts are applauded, they can’t completely resolve the problem of returns.

Technology Solutions

Sustainability startup companies are working to make it cost-effective for retailers to reduce their carbon footprints and eliminate landfills as a destination for returned goods.

For example, Alternew is a post-purchase software that enables brands to offer repair and alteration options more easily. The company focuses on addressing 70% of returns due to poor fit with a network of tailors that can connect with customers to reduce reverse logistics costs. Similarly, (re)vive takes returns and deadstock, making the necessary alterations to make them sellable again.

Upselling and downselling have also offered options outside of the landfill. Refibered utilizes AI and specialized machinery to detect even trace amounts of contamination in fibers and reuse those that are clean, aiming to reduce textile waste. It Goes Forward has introduced a concept of “peer-to-peer” returns. If a customer wants to return an item, they’ll put it back on the “shelf” with a discount. Once it’s purchased, it’ll be shipped anonymously directly from the existing customer to the new customer.

The highest net-impact solution is donating unsellable or excess inventory. By donating, not only are people in need able to receive high-quality products, but the retailer can also receive a tax benefit for doing so. Because the logistics and documentation of donating can be challenging, my company, LiquiDonate, offers software that integrates with existing systems to redirect select items directly from the customer to local nonprofits or schools while also handling the necessary documentation for tax filing. We help significantly lower returns logistics costs and create a sustainable, affordable option that prevents returns from being dumped in a landfill.

There is no end in sight for the rising cost of returns on businesses. It’s essential to explore options beyond the landfill to minimize the environmental impact.

About the Author

Disney Petit is a social impact entrepreneur and CEO of LiquiDonate, software that integrates with any WMS or RMS to match unsellable returns and overstock inventory with nonprofits and schools. She was employee #15 at Postmates, where she built the Civic Labs team and won Time Magazine Invention of the Year for the food security product known as Bento.
articles.reasoning: The article addresses the financial and environmental impacts of retail returns and suggests ways to avoid them, which implies progress toward reducing waste and environmental harm. This aligns with environmental progress and sustainability efforts, which are positive and hopeful topics.
articles.personality_title: Smart steps to cut the cost and waste of retail returns
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Over the past ten years, returning items to stores has gone from a simple process to a tricky challenge. Big companies like Amazon made free returns popular, so others had to follow. This put pressure on smaller shops, which struggle to cover return costs and shipping. Returns now cause money loss and harm the environment.

**What happened**
Experts are sharing ideas to fix this problem. They suggest smart shopping habits, clearer product descriptions, and better packaging to reduce returns. Stores can also improve how they handle returns to save money and cut waste. These changes help both businesses and customers.

**Impact**
By reducing returns, stores save money on shipping and restocking. Fewer returned items mean less waste and pollution, helping the planet. Smaller businesses stand a better chance to compete fairly without losing money on returns.

**What's next step**
The next step is for more retailers to adopt these smart return strategies. Shoppers can help by choosing products carefully and understanding return policies. Together, these actions will reduce unnecessary returns and their negative impact.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Simple changes in shopping and returns can save money, help small businesses, and protect the environment.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des gestes simples pour réduire le coût et le gaspillage des retours en magasin
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Au cours des dix dernières années, le retour des articles en magasin est passé d’un processus simple à un vrai casse-tête. Les grandes entreprises comme Amazon ont rendu les retours gratuits populaires, obligeant les autres à suivre. Cela a mis la pression sur les petits commerces, qui peinent à couvrir les coûts des retours et de l’expédition. Les retours causent maintenant des pertes d’argent et nuisent à l’environnement.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des experts partagent des idées pour résoudre ce problème. Ils recommandent de mieux choisir ses achats, d’avoir des descriptions de produits plus claires et un emballage adéquat pour réduire les retours. Les magasins peuvent aussi améliorer leur gestion des retours pour économiser de l’argent et réduire le gaspillage. Ces changements profitent à la fois aux commerces et aux clients.

**Impact**
En réduisant les retours, les magasins économisent sur l’expédition et la remise en rayon. Moins d’articles retournés signifie moins de déchets et de pollution, ce qui aide la planète. Les petits commerces ont plus de chances de rivaliser équitablement sans perdre d’argent à cause des retours.

**Prochaine étape**
La prochaine étape est que davantage de commerçants adoptent ces stratégies intelligentes sur les retours. Les acheteurs peuvent aussi aider en choisissant bien leurs produits et en comprenant les politiques de retour. Ensemble, ces actions réduiront les retours inutiles et leurs impacts négatifs.

**En une phrase**
Quelques changements simples dans les achats et les retours peuvent faire économiser de l’argent, aider les petits commerces et protéger l’environnement.
articles.personality_title_es: Pasos inteligentes para reducir el costo y el desperdicio de las devoluciones en tiendas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
En los últimos diez años, devolver productos a las tiendas pasó de ser algo sencillo a un desafío complicado. Grandes empresas como Amazon popularizaron las devoluciones gratuitas, lo que obligó a otros a hacer lo mismo. Esto presionó a los pequeños negocios, que tienen dificultades para cubrir los costos de las devoluciones y envíos. Ahora, las devoluciones provocan pérdidas económicas y dañan al medio ambiente.

**Qué pasó**
Expertos están compartiendo ideas para solucionar este problema. Sugieren hábitos de compra inteligentes, descripciones claras de productos y un mejor embalaje para reducir las devoluciones. Las tiendas también pueden mejorar cómo manejan las devoluciones para ahorrar dinero y reducir desperdicios. Estos cambios benefician tanto a negocios como a clientes.

**Impacto**
Al reducir las devoluciones, las tiendas ahorran en envíos y reposición de productos. Menos devoluciones significan menos desechos y contaminación, ayudando al planeta. Los pequeños negocios tienen más oportunidades de competir justamente sin perder dinero por las devoluciones.

**Próximo paso**
El siguiente paso es que más minoristas adopten estas estrategias inteligentes para las devoluciones. Los compradores pueden ayudar eligiendo bien sus productos y entendiendo las políticas de devolución. Juntos, estas acciones reducirán las devoluciones innecesarias y sus impactos negativos.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Cambios simples en las compras y devoluciones pueden ahorrar dinero, ayudar a los pequeños negocios y proteger el medio ambiente.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a balanced scale holding a neatly folded garment and a small, stylized warehouse on one side, and a vibrant patchwork quilt made from repurposed clothing pieces on the other, set against a soft, natural-toned background symbolizing sustainability and mindful consumption.

articles.title: Earth911 Podcast Classic: Sustainability at Home — Food, Detergents, and Reuse Projects
articles.summary:
Return to a classic episode of Sustainability In Your Ear, when the Earth911 team discussed...
The post Earth911 Podcast Classic: Sustainability at Home — Food, Detergents, and Reuse Projects appeared first on Earth911.
articles.content:
Return to a classic episode of Sustainability In Your Ear, when the Earth911 team discussed the sustainable household decisions and projects to think about if you have some extra coronavirus-isolation time on your hands. We look at four kinds of laundry detergent, including powdered, liquid, pod, and sheet detergents that are easier on your clothes and the environment. Thinking about a Mother’s Day or Father’s Day gift you can make yourself this year? Take a look at our guide to making an eco-conscious shaving kit or eight ways to reuse aluminum cans in DIY projects that also make fun gifts.

And we discuss the labeling of foods and a recent study by As You Sow, a nonprofit that examined the supply chains of major food producers for pesticide-use transparency. You’ll be surprised by which companies did well and some of the names of the laggards that are best to avoid if you want to know what you are eating.

In this week’s Earthling Questions, we explain how to recycle VHS tapes and used tires.

Subscribe to the podcast on iTunes.

Follow the podcast on Spreaker, iHeartRadio, or YouTube.

Editor’s Note: This podcast originally aired on August 31, 2020.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights sustainability efforts at home, focusing on food, detergents, and reuse projects, which align with environmental progress and conservation successes. These topics promote positive environmental action and encourage responsible living, making it uplifting and hopeful for a wide audience.
articles.personality_title: Making sustainability simple at home with food, detergents, and reuse projects
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
During the quieter days of coronavirus isolation, many people found time to rethink how they live more sustainably at home. The Earth911 team shared helpful ideas about everyday choices that protect the environment.

**What happened**
In a popular episode of their podcast, Earth911 talked about four types of laundry detergents—powdered, liquid, pod, and sheet. Each type has benefits for clothes and the planet. They also offered tips on homemade gift ideas for occasions like Mother’s or Father’s Day, encouraging eco-friendly creativity.

**Impact**
These simple swaps and projects show how small changes in our daily routines—like choosing better detergents or reusing items creatively—can reduce waste and pollution. It makes sustainability feel doable and rewarding for everyone.

**What's next step**
Listeners are invited to try these ideas at home, experiment with different detergents, and explore reuse projects. Sharing these habits can inspire more people to live greener, helping build a healthier planet.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Small, thoughtful choices at home can make a big difference for the environment and inspire a greener lifestyle.
articles.personality_title_fr: Simplifier la durabilité à la maison avec la nourriture, les détergents et les projets de réutilisation
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Pendant les journées plus calmes de l'isolement dû au coronavirus, beaucoup ont eu le temps de repenser leur mode de vie pour être plus durables à la maison. L'équipe Earth911 a partagé des idées utiles sur des choix quotidiens respectueux de l'environnement.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Dans un épisode populaire de leur podcast, Earth911 a parlé de quatre types de détergents à lessive — en poudre, liquide, en capsules et en feuilles. Chaque type présente des avantages pour les vêtements et la planète. Ils ont aussi proposé des idées de cadeaux faits maison pour la Fête des Mères ou des Pères, encourageant la créativité écologique.

**Impact**
Ces petits changements dans nos routines quotidiennes — comme choisir de meilleurs détergents ou réutiliser des objets de façon créative — peuvent réduire les déchets et la pollution. Cela rend la durabilité accessible et gratifiante pour tous.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les auditeurs sont invités à essayer ces idées chez eux, à tester différents détergents et à explorer des projets de réutilisation. Partager ces habitudes peut inspirer davantage de personnes à adopter un mode de vie plus vert.

**Une phrase clé à retenir**
De petits choix réfléchis à la maison peuvent avoir un grand impact pour l'environnement et encourager un mode de vie plus écologique.
articles.personality_title_es: Hacer la sostenibilidad sencilla en casa con alimentos, detergentes y proyectos de reutilización
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Durante los días tranquilos del aislamiento por coronavirus, muchas personas encontraron tiempo para repensar cómo vivir de manera más sostenible en casa. El equipo de Earth911 compartió ideas útiles sobre decisiones cotidianas que protegen el medio ambiente.

**Qué pasó**
En un episodio popular de su podcast, Earth911 habló sobre cuatro tipos de detergentes para ropa: en polvo, líquido, cápsulas y en hojas. Cada tipo tiene beneficios para la ropa y el planeta. También ofrecieron consejos para regalos caseros en ocasiones como el Día de la Madre o el Padre, fomentando la creatividad ecológica.

**Impacto**
Estos cambios simples y proyectos muestran cómo pequeñas modificaciones en nuestras rutinas diarias — como elegir mejores detergentes o reutilizar objetos de forma creativa — pueden reducir residuos y contaminación. Hace que la sostenibilidad sea accesible y gratificante para todos.

**Próximos pasos**
Se invita a los oyentes a probar estas ideas en casa, experimentar con diferentes detergentes y explorar proyectos de reutilización. Compartir estos hábitos puede inspirar a más personas a vivir de manera más ecológica.

**Una frase para recordar**
Pequeñas decisiones conscientes en casa pueden hacer una gran diferencia para el medio ambiente e inspirar un estilo de vida más verde.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm drawing of a cozy home kitchen scene featuring symbolic representations of eco-friendly laundry detergents—powder in a small open jar, liquid in a simple bottle, colorful detergent pods in a bowl, and thin sheets beside them—alongside creatively repurposed aluminum cans turned into charming handmade gifts, with subtle imagery of fresh fruits and vegetables labeled with transparent tags to suggest food safety and pesticide awareness, all rendered in soft natural tones and gentle lighting without any human figures.

articles.title: UN top court rules that failure to meet climate goals could lead to reparations
articles.summary: In a landmark ruling the UN's top court on Wednesday found that countries harmed by climate change could be entitled to reparations for the damage they have suffered. It also said that if countries fail to take measures to protect the planet from climate change, they could be in violation of international law.
articles.content:
Vanuatu's Climate Change Minister Ralph Regenvanu delivers a speech at a demonstration ahead of the International Court of Justice session in The Hague on July 23, 2025.

One of your browser extensions seems to be blocking the video player from loading. To watch this content, you may need to disable it on this site.

To display this content from YouTube, you must enable advertisement tracking and audience measurement.

The top UN court on Wednesday paved the way for the payment of possible reparations to be imposed on countries that breach climate change obligations – on a case-by-case basis.

"The legal consequences resulting from the commission of an internationally wrongful act may include ... full reparations to injured states in the form of restitution, compensation and satisfaction," the court said.

The court added that a "sufficient direct and certain causal nexus" had to be shown "between the wrongful act and the injury".

The International Court of Justice gave the remarks as an advisory opinion in a landmark case about nations’ obligations to tackle climate change and the consequences they may face if they don’t, calling it an “urgent and existential” threat to humanity.

“Failure of a state to take appropriate action to protect the climate system ... may constitute an internationally wrongful act,” court President Yuji Iwasawa said during the hearing.

The non-binding opinion, which runs to over 500 pages, is seen as a potential turning point in international climate law.

The court said a “clean, healthy and sustainable environment” is a human right. Enshrining a sustainable environment as a human right paves the way for other legal actions, including states returning to the ICJ to hold each other to account as well as domestic lawsuits, along with legal instruments like investment agreements.

The case is led by the Pacific island nation of Vanuatu and backed by more than 130 countries.

All UN member states including major greenhouse gas emitters like the United States and China are parties to the court.

Outside the court, climate activists gathered with a banner that read: “Courts have spoken. The law is clear. States must ACT NOW.” The courtroom, known as the Great Hall of Justice, was packed.

After years of lobbying by vulnerable island nations who fear they could disappear under rising sea waters, the UN General Assembly asked the ICJ in 2023 for an advisory opinion, an important basis for international obligations.

A panel of 15 judges was tasked with answering two questions: What are countries obliged to do under international law to protect the climate and environment from human-caused greenhouse gas emissions? Second, what are the legal consequences for governments when their acts, or lack of action, have significantly harmed the climate and environment?

“The stakes could not be higher. The survival of my people and so many others is on the line,” Arnold Kiel Loughman, attorney general of the island nation of Vanuatu, told the court during a week of hearings in December.

In the decade up to 2023, sea levels rose by a global average of around 4.3 centimetres (1.7 inches), with parts of the Pacific rising higher still. The world has also warmed 1.3 degrees Celsius (2.3 Fahrenheit) since pre-industrial times because of the burning of fossil fuels.

Simply having the court issue an opinion is the latest in a series of legal victories for the small island nations.

Earlier this month, the Inter-American Court of Human Rights found that countries have a legal duty not only to avoid environmental harm but also to protect and restore ecosystems. Last year, the European Court of Human Rights ruled that countries must better protect their people from the consequences of climate change.

Read moreSmall island states hail 'historic' victory in UN climate case

In 2019, the Netherlands' Supreme court handed down the first major legal win for climate activists when judges ruled that protection from the potentially devastating effects of climate change was a human right and that the government has a duty to protect its citizens.

(FRANCE 24 with AP and AFP)
articles.reasoning: The UN top court ruling holds countries accountable for climate change damage and could incentivize stronger environmental protection measures, which is a positive step toward addressing climate change and supporting affected communities.
articles.personality_title: UN court says countries must pay for climate damage if they fail to act
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Climate change is causing serious harm around the world, especially in vulnerable countries. Until now, it was unclear if nations could be held legally responsible for the damage caused by their actions or inactions on climate.

**What happened**
The United Nations’ highest court made a landmark decision. It ruled that countries suffering from climate change damage could receive reparations—financial compensation—from those who fail to meet climate goals. The court also said ignoring climate protection measures may break international law.

**Impact**
This ruling holds countries accountable for their role in climate change. It encourages stronger environmental policies and gives hope to communities already affected by climate disasters. By linking legal responsibility to climate action, the decision pushes nations to do better to protect the planet.

**What's next step**
Affected countries can now seek reparations if harmed by climate change. Meanwhile, nations are likely to review and strengthen their climate commitments to avoid legal consequences. This could lead to more urgent and effective climate action worldwide.

**One-sentence takeaway**
The UN court’s decision makes it clear: failing to protect the planet could cost countries financially and legally, encouraging stronger climate action for everyone.
articles.personality_title_fr: La cour de l’ONU affirme que les pays doivent payer pour les dommages climatiques s’ils n’agissent pas
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le changement climatique cause de graves dégâts dans le monde, surtout dans les pays vulnérables. Jusqu’à présent, il n’était pas clair si les nations pouvaient être légalement responsables des dommages causés par leurs actions ou inactions sur le climat.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
La plus haute cour des Nations Unies a pris une décision historique. Elle a statué que les pays victimes des dégâts liés au climat pourraient recevoir des réparations - une compensation financière - de la part de ceux qui ne respectent pas leurs objectifs climatiques. La cour a aussi dit que ne pas prendre de mesures pour protéger le climat peut violer le droit international.

**Impact**
Cette décision rend les pays responsables de leur rôle dans le changement climatique. Elle encourage des politiques environnementales plus fortes et donne de l’espoir aux communautés déjà touchées. En liant responsabilité juridique et action climatique, la décision pousse les nations à mieux protéger la planète.

**Prochaine étape**
Les pays concernés peuvent maintenant demander des réparations en cas de dommages climatiques. En même temps, les nations vont probablement revoir et renforcer leurs engagements climatiques pour éviter des conséquences juridiques. Cela pourrait entraîner une action climatique plus urgente et efficace dans le monde.

**En une phrase**
La décision de la cour de l’ONU est claire : ne pas protéger la planète pourrait coûter cher aux pays, financièrement et légalement, ce qui encourage une action climatique plus forte pour tous.
articles.personality_title_es: El tribunal de la ONU dice que los países deben pagar por daños climáticos si no actúan
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El cambio climático está causando graves daños en todo el mundo, especialmente en países vulnerables. Hasta ahora, no estaba claro si las naciones podían ser legalmente responsables por los daños causados por sus acciones o inacciones sobre el clima.

**Qué pasó**
El tribunal más alto de la ONU tomó una decisión histórica. Dictaminó que los países afectados por daños climáticos podrían recibir reparaciones, es decir, compensación económica, de aquellos que no cumplan con las metas climáticas. Además, señaló que no tomar medidas para proteger el planeta puede violar la ley internacional.

**Impacto**
Esta decisión hace responsables a los países por su papel en el cambio climático. Fomenta políticas ambientales más fuertes y da esperanza a las comunidades ya afectadas. Al vincular la responsabilidad legal con la acción climática, impulsa a las naciones a proteger mejor el planeta.

**Próximo paso**
Los países afectados ahora pueden buscar reparaciones si sufren daños por el cambio climático. Mientras tanto, las naciones probablemente revisarán y reforzarán sus compromisos climáticos para evitar consecuencias legales. Esto podría llevar a una acción climática más urgente y efectiva a nivel mundial.

**Una frase clave**
La decisión del tribunal de la ONU es clara: no proteger el planeta puede costar caro a los países, financiera y legalmente, lo que impulsa una acción climática más fuerte para todos.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a peaceful oceanic scene featuring a small, vibrant Pacific island gently embraced by protective, translucent scales shaped like a balanced set of justice scales hovering above the island, symbolizing legal protection and reparations, with calm waves reflecting soft, natural blues and greens under a clear sky, evoking hope and unity in the face of climate change.
